## Big data versus multidimensional data

I don't believe in big data, but I do believe in multidimensional data. 

## Generalized pairs plot

Do you know the scatterplot matrix or pairs plot? Generally, it looks like this:

```{r pairsplot}
plot(mtcars)
```

## 

That's a lot to look at, so lets take a subset:
```{r subpairsplot, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(dplyr)
select(mtcars, mpg, cyl, disp) %>% plot()
```

## Generalized pairs plot (citation)

The pairs plot is useful on its own, but the generalized pairs plot is even better.

Emerson, J. W., Green, W. A., Schloerke, B., Crowley, J., Cook, D., Hofmann, H., and Wickham, H. (2013). The generalized pairs plot. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, 22(1):79â€“91. 

[http://bit.ly/gpairs](http://bit.ly/gpairs)

## 

```{r gpairsplot}
library(gpairs)
gpairs(mtcars)
```

## Grand Tour

The Grand Tour lets you explore multidimensional data more generically. 

##
```{r tourr, custom_plot=TRUE, fig.show='animate', fig.ext='png', echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, out.width='2.5in',fig.num=190}
library(tourr)
tourr::render(flea[, 1:6], grand_tour(d = 2), display = display_xy(), frames=190, apf=1/19, dev="png", fig_path("%1d.png"), width=240, height=240)
#tourr::animate(flea[, 1:6], grand_tour(d = 2), display = display_xy(), fps=19,  max_frames=100)
Sys.sleep(1)
```
